A Love-Hate Relationship: From Great Game to Cash Grab
I loved this game and will probably always love it, but lately, playing it feels like a constant struggle. I cannot recommend this game to new players as the developer continuously makes the experience worse for both new and endgame players. I will change my review if the situation improves.

The core issue is that the developer has shifted focus from creating a fun experience to aggressively monetizing progress. What was once a delightful incremental game has become a blatant grind and a heavy-handed push toward pay-to-win mechanics.

üì¢ Updates (Follower Progression)
UPDATE: The New Reality (Reinstalled to Check) I installed the game again, hoping things had changed for the better. The very next day, a new patch dropped, introducing a new real-money currency. This new system put roughly hundreds of dollars worth of pay-to-win benefits behind this currency, giving access to some of the most broken advantages in the game with no way to grind it in-game.

The developer also never fixed a major technical flaw I complained about ages ago (a progression limit), instead simply capping it at a ridiculously low number considering the current power creep. Capping the number-go-up dopamine in an incremental game is a sin.

Adding insult to injury, I ran into a bizarre bug where random screen elements would open a link to the developer's stream. My initial review still stands: the developer is still prioritizing questionable decisions.

UPDATE 2: Censorship Confirmed I was quickly banned from the game's community forum for making a single, critical post about the recent paywall additions. This kind of heavy-handed censorship confirms the developer's unwillingness to take valid feedback.

UPDATE 3: Banned for Feedback Shortly after writing my original notes, I was banned from the game's official chat for criticizing the latest patch and how it negatively affects free-to-play players, failing to deliver on promised fixes.

üëç The Good (What I Loved)
Excellent Progression Systems: The game offers deep and engaging mechanics to constantly strive for improvement.

Unique Character Control: The ability to manage multiple characters without constant active grinding is cool and efficient.

Satisfaction of Scale: Resource management and hoarding billions of items creates a genuine feeling of power.

Visual Appeal: The pixel art style is great, and the monsters are interesting and quirky.

Constant Goals: There is always something new to strive for and systems to min-max.

Uncapped Progress: Most core systems, like character levels, have no limit, which is the heart of an incremental game.

Community: The player base is generally nice and helpful.

üëé The Bad (The P2W Shift)
Escalating Costs to Compete: Each new world significantly increases the amount of store currency you must spend to maintain a competitive edge, with some updates offering massive power boosts only via spending.

Aggressive Currency Nerfs: The acquisition of the in-game store currency is constantly being nerfed. A major boss that used to reward a decent amount of the currency now drops a fraction of that.

More Store Purchases, Less F2P Currency: The developer continually adds more store purchases with each patch while simultaneously reducing the rate at which players can earn the currency for free.

Ignoring Critical Bugs for Months: Despite promises of QOL and bug-fix focused patches, the most crippling, long-standing bugs (like mobile progression overflow) are consistently ignored.

QOL = Nerfs in Disguise: Many "Quality of Life" updates end up being major nerfs with minor cosmetic improvements. Recent party-finding QOL, for example, completely broke the system.

Endgame Punishment: Endgame players are repeatedly nerfed in damage and overall progression.

Developer's Ego and Refusal to Listen: A lot of the frustrating problems stem from the developer's refusal to accept help or listen to the smart, talented programmers within the community.

Poor Communication and Emotional Responses: The developer's communication is lacking, and his responses to criticism are often emotionally charged or dismissive (e.g., suggesting players just "don't use" a flawed feature).

üíÄ The Ugly (The Environment)
Zero Tolerance for Criticism: Any form of negative feedback is deemed "toxic" by the developer and often results in an immediate ban.

History of Censorship: The developer has a track record of censoring his critics, taking down community videos, demanding name changes from content creators, and banning people for petty reasons.

Arbitrary Bans: Active, long-time community members and even staff have been suddenly banned for minor or unclear reasons, demonstrating a severe lack of transparency and an authoritarian management style.

Developer's Priorities: The developer adds features he "wants" rather than what the game needs, spending time on minor cosmetic additions while core systems remain broken.

Toxic Requirement to Compete: To exploit developer oversights (bugs that often provide massive advantages for months), you are effectively required to be active in the community chats. This forces players to navigate an unpredictable and often hostile environment just to stay competitive.

Cheater Immunity: Cheaters are able to roam the game freely, while legitimate players are banned for criticism.

I urge those who get deeply invested in their games to proceed with extreme caution if you still decide to try this game.

The game has tons of charm, content, and fun to be had for nerdier folks that like to optimize their numbers going up, but it is marred by everything surrounding it, from excessive and predatory monetization to awful community mismanagement.  

[h2]The positives:[/h2] 

The art style is incredibly charming, with every map featuring a new adorable creature you must murder for the sake of loot and progression. The music is likewise lovely to listen to, though you'll likely be muting it if you play long-term. The writing is full of dorky references and jokes, which can sometimes be a little cringy, but they're fun and the game doesn't take itself too seriously, which I personally am quite fond of.  

The game's progression is incredibly deep and layered, but you always have a simple goal to help keep you moving forward: kill enough enemies to progress to the next map, all the way until the world's boss, so you can open the next world. This keeps the game from becoming too overwhelming too quickly.  

Each world (7 at the time of writing) has 3 main skills (7 currently only has 1, with more coming soon), with additional secondary mechanics also being spread throughout. Skills in the same world tend to be interlinked with eachother, creating a feedback loop of improvement, which makes working on each skill satisfying and rewarding. Later skills also often improve ones from previous worlds, meaning each world continues to stay relevant even as you unlock new ones. All of this, alongside additional subsystems, which tend to be more independent, and getting to manage up to 10 characters all at once, each with their own proficiencies, means you've always got something to do to improve your account, and it makes for a fun game of managing what you should improve next to maximize your gains.  

[h2]The negatives:[/h2]  

The game is incredibly buggy. Mobile players especially tend to receive the worst of this due to the limitations of the mobile client, things like damage and experience rates rolling over into the negative, sometimes locking them out of the game entirely due to crashes. The performance can also be pretty terrible at times. No game is perfect, and bug fixes do happen every so often, but it's prevalent enough to be a significant mark on the game.  

The late game experience is full of unpleasant game mechanics and optimizations that take the joy out of progression. Things like Tower Defense taking literal hours for a single wave, because the enemies can't kill you, so you just have to wait until your puny damage kills them to set a new high score (which comes with account benefits). Or "Candy clicking", using Time Candy to obtain billions of materials which you can't reasonably hold all at once, which means you have to repeatedly fill up your inventory, then stash it to your bank (p2w mechanic, will cover shortly), to then improve your stats dramatically beyond what a player who does not engage in this tactic can reasonably achieve. Or the excessive overreliance on daily logins and activities, where opening the game for five minutes matters more than actually playing it sometimes, and makes Golden Stopwatches, which function simply to trigger a daily reset, one of the most powerful and sought after consumables in the whole game.  

The game is incredibly pay to win. A mechanic in World 4 checks various statistics across your entire account, and gives you a score, which is then compared to other players. As of 1.0, this mechanic now gives extremely powerful rewards, which, coupled with the immense power of cash-exclusive benefits, makes this p2w in the purest sense of the phrase.  

As for the benefits themselves, they come in layers. First is the gem shop, which is technically accessible to everyone. However, gems can be purchased, the benefits in the shop are very powerful, and the developer has been continuously, silently nerfing the ability of players to earn gems for free, making purchasing gems more and more enticing. Especially once considering that there's a rotating "fomo shop" that's incredibly difficult to buy out regularly if you do not purchase gem packs, even without having to think about the permanent content.  

Then there's the gem packs themselves. Each one offers some kind of item equippable by your characters, and also often come with permanent account boosts. Some of them are as simple as multipliers to various stats, some come with unique mechanics and benefits to specific skills or subsystems. As of world 7, any package that comes with a Trophy or Nametag now essentially comes with another account boost, as these items are no longer required to be equipped, and work across the entire account. Not all packs are made equal, but pretty much every pack in the last 2 years has dramatically increased the gap between a free player and someone who purchases every new pack, with seemingly no intent to change that. The results of this gap can be pretty clearly felt in World 7, where huge penalties are in place to slow down progression, but paying players can overcome them much easier because their damage, drop rates and even AFK gains are multiplied by absurd amounts, and they have a surplus of gems to spend on the new gem shop upgrades to improve their skilling and obtain gains much faster.  

Companions get their own section because fuck gambling. This is technically accessible to everyone, but non-paying players get to try the roulette [i]once a week[/i]. The only way to get more spins is to pay real money for crystals, which are just green colored gems with no free alternative. Each companion comes with account boosts, with the common ones being really mediocre if not outright useless, and the rare ones being very strong and desirable. The free player, of course, will get 90% commons, with duplicates being very common, which free players get absolutely no use out of. Paying players can actually trade their pets with others or gift them, and they also have access to a pity system, meaning they will eventually get what they want, even if it costs them $200 to do so. Disgusting mechanic and it's not getting any better even 2 years later.  

All of this complaining I've done already would not fly in the game's official Discord server, as the developer is incredibly fond of censorship of dissenting opinions. With how complicated the game gets later on, it lives and dies by its community, which the developer has no issue trampling on, as a major contributor to the wiki has recently been banned with no reason given and no ability to appeal. The fallout is going to be very interesting to see.  

[h2]Conclusion:[/h2]  

It's a game I love dearly, but I refuse to financially support, because what happens outside of just the game itself matters to me, and what's happening is incredibly foul and indefensible. It's fun to hop on whenever a new update arrives, but I'll inevitably get burnt out again doing my 30th day of wage slaving for a meager sum of gems and become disillusioned by the game yet again. Don't play this unless you have money to throw around or have an easier time tolerating bullshit than most people.

Don‚Äôt let my hours fool you. The game incentivizes ‚ÄúAFK‚Äù play, meaning it‚Äôs designed to sit open in the background while you do other things. There is actually little to do in the game outside of micromanaging poorly designed systems, and seeing numbers get bigger.

It can help pass the time when you‚Äôre bored, but it isn‚Äôt a good game. Lots of game-breaking bugs, major systems feel half-finished & repetitive, monetization is predatory, and player time is usually disrespected.

Here are some examples that I've tried to explain in a way that you can understand if you're new.
TLDR though; play if you want, but when you hit the point that you need Autoloot? Quit, and just go play maplestory. Nexon will treat you better. (Shocking, I know.)

Examples of Problems
- Daily minigames and multipliers
You can build up reward multipliers by skipping a day, but two major issues ruin the system. If you crash (and crashes are common) you lose the run and the multiplier. And because the minigames are pure RNG, a single bad roll can also make you the run and the multiplier. Days of multiplier buildup just gone with very little (Or nothing) you've gained. The game also literally insults you when you fail, which gets old fast.

- Severe lag
When the game lags, it slows to a crawl and behaves as if you‚Äôre offline. Attacks cast slower, kills drop, UI interactions break, and the game can freeze your entire PC until you restart. For something meant to run in the background, this really should have been fixed years ago.

- Pay-to-win
I don‚Äôt mind P2W packs since I treat them like I would a FFXIV subscription, but the presentation of most P2W elements is just awful. For example a past event introduced a limited-time nametag with major drop-rate multiplier. If you didn‚Äôt play or gamble for it during that event, tough luck. You‚Äôll never reach the same progression curve as people who did. Oh, and you also needed to gamble enough (with money) to have won it 5 times since the newest updates introduced a "stacking" system for name tags. You wouldn't have known this at the time though.

- Gambling everywhere
Pets are obtained through RNG rolls where high-tier pets drastically change gameplay, and you will likely never get them unless you're willing to spend at-least $50+. Events always have a ‚ÄúWheel‚Äù with only a couple worthwhile prizes, and the best ones are never brought back into the game. The game advertises ‚Äúguaranteed‚Äù rewards for F2P, but unless you bought packs or extra spins, you couldn‚Äôt actually meet the threshold. This creates constant FOMO and pushes players toward spending even more money. Not to mention that past events had a guaranteed win system that repeated. Once you got the guarantee the counter reset. Now the most recent event completely removed that system. You get 1 guarantee. After? You gotta gamble a LOT.

- QoL problems
Many systems are outdated or poorly designed. Some require repetitive clicking (Or tapping on mobile) for long periods which I am sure is not good for your wrist. Newer systems rarely have a reset option, so a single uninformed mistake permanently locks you out of progress. 

- Artificial progression walls
There are many fake walls, but the best example are the new "MasterClasses". These are the final job advancement for a specific class. They do not release with a way to gain the class's currency while offline. Instead if you want to get class currency you need to exclusively play them, and then when the next update is dropped that's when the offline mechanic is introduced. It's a system clearly designed around artificial inconvenience just so players don't progress as fast on these classes. The most ironic thing about it is that usually you can catch up to people who have played that class actively since released because of how the offline mechanism works; so unless you REALLY wanna play the class; don't bother. Just wait for the next update.

- Developer relations
The developer removes negative reviews anywhere he can, and he'll also ban whoever said them too if possible. Giveaways used to be cosmetic; now they grant permanent account boosts and are often given preferentially to Twitch subscribers or Discord users who advertise for the game (Via the tag system.) Arcade currency multipliers are determined through twitch chat ‚Äúgames‚Äù where the developer rarely actually polls the chat for answers; he just picks them arbitrarily based on the most "common" answer he sees which strangely enough is usually the wrong answer.
One recent example of this was him playing omok with the chat. Chat was gonna lose every game so he decided to just give a 1.8x multiplier instead of continuing to play. There was some backlash (And the game was surging in popularity at the time) so he decided to alter that multiplier the next day up a 2.2x multiplier. If you had saved up arcade currency for months (Or spent money to get more currency), and spent that currency to gamble the day it was 1.8x then too bad so sad. There was no retroactive application or anything like that. You just lost out on 22% of what you should've had to begin with. 
Oh, and if that wasn't bad enough all of the newest Arcade bonuses also cost 10x more than all of the other ones. This is a new change, and I believe was designed around incentivizing people to gamble with money instead of F2P currency. Generally there are just a lot of patterns that show a consistent disregard for players/money/time.

- Multiplatform issues
The game claims it has cross-platform support, but that only works early game and only if you‚Äôre not logged into another device. You must manually cloud save or you'll lose progress with no warning. Mobile also suffers from number overflow bugs that can convert offline gains into negative values and permanently delete resources. Damage overflow still happens as well, but is now more of an end-game issue because of the latest update.

There are more issues: misleading claims about F2P premium currency access, overpromised roadmaps, and the fact that autoloot is effectively mandatory. But the problem is just that the game constantly wastes your time, pressures you with gambling, and offers little respect or reward in return. 

If you do choose to try it, treat it like a throwaway idle title and avoid anything involving premium currency, wheels, or other gambling mechanics. Gambling is a very easy thing to become addicted to, and this game tries its best to be that addiction.

Well, I still quite enjoy the gameplay. But the p2w has suddenly skyrocketed. New huge packs coming every few days, lots of fomo, and changing them out so quickly people are worried about missing them.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]

Idleon is one of the most in depth idle games I've ever played. It's the ultimate progression game - every world comes with new mini idle games that provide overall stats and progression to your account. 

You get to control up to 10 characters (that you have to progress to unlock, obviously). While one is mining the ore you need, the other can be pushing worlds to progress, and another can be farming materials you need. It all comes together in a very satisfying way and gives me everything I love about maplestory progression and runescape leveling, but able to grind without clicking on a new tree every 10 seconds.

There also is a TON of content - this game has been out for years. Some people don't like this, as they won't be end game immediately, but it gives you tons to do and lots of progression to make.

[h2] In game purchases [/h2]

There are many complaints about p2w in this review section. I would say that the game probably needs a baseline of at least the pack that provides autoloot, which is 5$. Personally, I don't mind a small paywall in a free to play game, as obviously developers need to support themselves somehow.

That being said, there are some greedier packs and mechanics. But in my opinion, it's really mild compared to many "freemium" games. This isn't afk arena that's encouraging you to spend 100$ every time you hit a new milestone. There are 20$ packs that rotate in every couple of weeks or when a major pack drops. Generally, these have good value and come with cosmetics. Gems are actually extremely farmable if you bother to do quests or even just farm.

But none of it is required at all to progress - you will powerscale on your own just fine. Paying will skip the time spent grinding . As there are no competitive aspects to the game this doesn't bother me. If you don't have good self control, maybe skip this one.

I've had some fun times with this game but there's just too many issues for me to recommend it.

1. Heavy use of non-cosmetic microtransactions. While the game is technically free-to-play, you can pour hundreds of dollars into it for things that give you substantial gameplay advantages. One of these, the autoloot package, is considered by many players to be pretty much required for progression beyond a certain point, so many people consider accounts that have bought it to still be "free-to-play" accounts. Another argument frequently brought up is that the game is supposedly a single-player game, and thus, the microtransactions are not an issue. I believe that if it truly were single-player, there would be no problem with me modding the game to give myself those bonuses to make my experience more enjoyable, but modding is a bannable offense. (Additionally, there are several parts of the game that actively require or at least heavily reward co-op gameplay with others.)
2. Heavy use of FOMO (fear of missing out) to promote constant engagement. The game frequently uses limited-time events to encourage players to log in every day and push for more gems/event minigame plays or risk permanently missing out on bonuses and falling behind everyone else (which wouldn't bother me as much if not for the next point.) I feel like this is somewhat manipulative and reminds me a lot of Nintendo's practices with limited-time giveaways of mythical Pokemon (except that I have more of an issue with this, because unlike with Pokemon, it's significantly harder and grounds for an account ban to mod your account to have the limited-time bonus.)
3. Many of my interactions with the community have been pretty unpleasant. Lots of experienced players will look down on and criticize others for not playing the game the way it "should" be played. I wouldn't mind this as much, if not for the fact that it's a multiplayer game which basically requires engaging with the community to at least some degree, and the wiki is often outdated, particularly around the time of recent updates, with the reasoning that they don't want to spoil new players, and people can just go to the Discord for information.
4. There are lots of pitfalls you can make that end up hampering your progress that are either irreversible or will hamper your attempts to make progress, such as mis-spending prisma bubbles, buying Laboratory Bling before acquiring enough of the chips/jewels it will replace in rotation, or using Fisharoo Reset too frequently on Poppy. If this were a single-player game that could be played locally, this wouldn't be an issue, since you could simply have backup savefiles.

If IdleOn were a game that could be played locally, with minor wireless and co-op features, and there weren't rules against modding, I would enjoy the game a lot more and would probably be leaving a positive review, because that would mitigate almost all of my issues with the game.
